snippet: The interim government agreed to cut spending this year by 1.5 percent of Greece’s gross domestic product, but members have yet to agree on details of austerity measures.
abstract: Greek interim government, responding to pressure by its foreign lenders, agrees to drastically cut spending in 2012 by 1.5 percent of the country's gross domestic product, but members have yet to agree on details of austerity measures, potentially jeopardizing the whole arrangement.

byline.original: By RACHEL DONADIO and NIKI KITSANTONIS
byline.contributor: Stephen Castle contributed reporting from London, and Jack Ewing from Frankfurt.

lead_paragraph: The interim government agreed to cut spending this year by 1.5 percent of Greece’s gross domestic product, but members have yet to agree on details of austerity measures.

headline.seo: Greece Agrees to Harsh New Spending Cuts
headline.main: Greece Agrees to Harsh New Spending Cuts as Lenders Ratchet Up the Pressure
headline.print_headline: Greece Agrees to Harsh New Cuts in Spending, but Talks on Lending Continue
